instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00244: What is 820-00244? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.5V_S0: What is 5V_S0? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S0”.
definitions.3V3_S0: What is 3V3_S0? Abbreviation for PP3V3_S0, a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, No Power, VCORE .79v
threads.message:
I started a thread for this one last week, but the information I had on it wasn't solid at the time. I started a new thread to keep things clean from the start:

1. Board gets warm as normal, but there's no chime/boot/life, aside from the board having all primary rails--<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>3V3R3V0_AON</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>5V_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>VRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL>, etc.
2. CPU gets very warm, but I measured cpu vcore at .79v. Should this be closer to 1.0v like on other boards? Schematic says 1.8v, but I know that's the highest, not average.

I don't have high hopes for this board, but wanted to ask before breaking the news to the customer. I don't even know what else to check on these, but I can provide any other measurements requested. Thanks so much, as usual, the help is tremendously appreciated.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, No Power, VCORE .79v
threads.message: History? Liquid? .79V seems ok for a board that has finished POST. Connect a mouse and see if it lights.
